{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Swedish Work Environment Authority |nativename = {{lang|sv|Arbetsmiljöverket (AV)}} |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = |logo_width = |logo_caption = |seal = Arbetsmiljöverket vapen.svg |seal_width = 110px |seal_caption = The [[coat of arms]] of the Swedish Work Environment Authority |picture = |picture_width = |picture_caption = |formed = 2001 |preceding1 = Regional Labour Inspectorate districts, |preceding2 = The National Board of Occupational Safety and Health |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[Government of Sweden]] |headquarters = Lindhagensgatan 133
[[Stockholm]] |coordinates = |employees = 555 (2013){{cite web|title=Årsredovisning 2013|url=http://www.av.se/dokument/omoss/av_arsredovisning13%20.pdf|publisher=AV|accessdate=12 August 2014|language=Swedish}} |budget = [[Swedish krona|SEK]] 505M (2013) |minister1_name = [[Ylva Johansson]] |minister1_pfo = ([[Ministry of Employment (Sweden)|Ministry of Employment]]) |minister2_name = |minister2_pfo = |chief1_name = [[Erna Zelmin-Ekenhem]] |chief1_position = ([[Director-General]]) |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |agency_type = |parent_agency = [[Ministry of Employment (Sweden)|Ministry of Employment]] |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |keydocument1= [http://www.esv.se/Verktyg--stod/Statsliggaren/Regleringsbrev/?RBID=15655 Regleringsbrev] |website = [http://www.av.se/inenglish/ av.se] |footnotes = }} The '''Swedish Work Environment Authority''' ('''SWEA''') ({{lang-sv|Arbetsmiljöverket}}, abbreviated ''AV'') is a [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[Government agencies in Sweden|administrative authority]] sorting under the [[Ministry of Employment (Sweden)|Ministry of Employment]], responsible for issues relating to the working environment and [[Occupational injury|work injury]] statistics. The agency is tasked by the [[Government of Sweden|Government]] with issuing regulations, should spread information and furnish advice on [[occupational safety and health]] (OSH), and the relating labour laws, in particular the [http://www.av.se/inenglish/lawandjustice/workact/ Work Environment Act] ([https://www.riksdagen.se/sv/Dokument-Lagar/Lagar/Svenskforfattningssamling/Arbetsmiljolag-19771160_sfs-1977-1160/ AML]). This is primarily done with the [http://www.av.se/inenglish/lawandjustice/provisions/ Work Environment Authority's Statute Book] (AFS), which contains provisions and general recommendations specifying the requirements to be met by the work environment. The agency also publishes other books, brochures, reports and should promote collaboration between parties on the labour market, on issues relating to OSH. Furthermore, the agency has a supervisory role for the compliance of the occupational health legislation, the Working Hours Act ([http://www.riksdagen.se/sv/Dokument-Lagar/Lagar/Svenskforfattningssamling/Arbetstidslag-1982673_sfs-1982-673/ SFS 1982:673]) and, in certain aspects, the Tobacco Act ([http://www.riksdagen.se/sv/Dokument-Lagar/Lagar/Svenskforfattningssamling/Tobakslag-1993581_sfs-1993-581/?bet=1993:581 SFS 1993:581]) and the Environmental Code ([http://www.riksdagen.se/sv/Dokument-Lagar/Lagar/Svenskforfattningssamling/Miljobalk-1998808_sfs-1998-808/ SFS 1998:808]). This is usually done with inspections, and for this purpose, the agency has the right to issue stipulations and [[injunction]]s to any non-compliant employer.{{cite web|title=About us|url=http://www.av.se/inenglish/about/|publisher=AV}}{{cite web|title=Förordning (2007:913) med instruktion för Arbetsmiljöverket|url=http://www.riksdagen.se/sv/Dokument-Lagar/Lagar/Svenskforfattningssamling/Forordning-2007913-med-inst_sfs-2007-913/|publisher=The [[Riksdag]]|accessdate=12 August 2014|language=Swedish}} ==See also== *[[European Agency for Safety and Health at Work]] *[[International Labour Organization]] *[[Occupational safety and health]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.av.se/inenglish/ Swedish Work Environment Authority - Official Site] (English) [[Category:Government agencies of Sweden]] [[Category:Occupational safety and health organizations]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in Sweden]]

[[File:MINDS Foundation logo.jpeg|thumb|The MINDS Foundation logo.]] '''The MINDS Foundation''', a [[nonprofit]] located in [[India]], uses a [[grassroots]] approach to eliminate [[Social stigma|stigma]] and provide educational, medical, and moral support for patients with [[mental illness]] in rural India. (1) The organization conducts ongoing research and develops curriculum to expand education about mental health and increase the number of trained staff who can support patients suffering from mental illness. MINDS works with a broad team of directors, advisors, field workers and assistants and receives support through a variety of foundations, grants and [[NGO]]s. Since its creation in 2010, MINDS has increased the level of education and treatment with regards to mental illness, overcoming many of the challenges of rural health work in [[India]].
== Approach == MINDS uses a three-phase approach for education, treatment and reintegration. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:MINDS Foundation systematic change model.png|thumb|three phase system]] -->
'''Phase 1''' focuses on community-wide education held in each village by social workers, MINDS staff and Community Mental Health Workers. After a short 45-minute film explaining the basics of mental illness and the effectiveness of treatment, there are facilitated discussions and Q&A sessions which focus on de-stigmatization of mental illness. Research suggests that lack of health education in rural India contributes to serious misunderstandings, stigma and denial about the existence and causes of mental illness.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Magnier|first1=Mark|title=India Battles Misconceptions on Mental Illness|journal=Movement for Global Mental Health (Originally published in the LA Times)|date=7/5/2013|url=http://www.globalmentalhealth.org/india-battles-misconceptions-mental-illness}}</ref> According to current studies, psychologists believe education programs about [[mental illness]] are one of the most effective ways to reduce this [[Social stigma|stigma]] and encourage patients to receive the treatment they need.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mann|first1=Caroline|last2=Himelein|first2=Melissa|title=Putting the person back into psychopathology: an intervention to reduce mental illness stigma in the classroom|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00127-008-0324-2|doi=10.1007/s00127-008-0324-2|volume=43|journal=Social Psychiatry and Psychiatric Epidemiology|pages=545–551}}</ref>
'''Phase 2''' focuses on effective, free treatment for any mentally ill person who wishes to receive help. MINDS is committed to working in relation with communities and hospitals across [[Gujarat]] and, therefore, provides free daily transport to local hospitals, free consultation with local doctors and free medication. Furthermore, to ease the treatment process, families of patients are welcome to accompany the patients to the hospitals and doctors appointments. According to the [[National Alliance on Mental Illness]], 70-90% of all global mentally ill patients who receive treatment partially or completely recover.<ref>{{cite web|last1=National Alliance on Mental Illness|url=http://www.nami.org/template.cfm?section=about_mental_illness}}</ref>
'''Phase 3''' focuses on each patient's [[:wikt:reintegration|reintegration]] into the local community after treatment. With the help of Community Mental Health Workers, patients receive continued medical support and education. Families of patients also benefit from support and education during this transition. The Phase 1 education and de-stigmatization pave the way for this third phase of MINDS work.
== Programs and Research == In addition to the three-phase program running in villages across [[Gujarat]], [[India]], MINDS continually develops programs and conducts research to expand programing. Below is a summary of current, developing programing.
'''Community Mental Health Worker (CMHW) Training''' Community Mental Health Workers (CMHWs) work as [[advisors]] and [[mentors]] in each village where MINDS programming is run. The CMHWs go through extensive training that focuses on identifying [[mental illness]], connecting patients to hospital care, advising and educating families of mentally ill, supporting the phase 3 [[:wikt:reintegration|reintegration]] process and facilitating phase 1 education workshops. The training for CMHWs was developed in partnership with the Nossal Institute for Global Health, adapted from ''An Introduction to Mental Health: Facilitator’s Manual for Training Community Health Workers in India by the Nossal Institute for Global Health & BasicNeeds''<ref>{{cite book|last1=The Nossal Institute for Global Health & Basic Needs'|title=An Introduction to Mental Health: Facilitator’s Manual for Training Community Health Workers in India}}</ref>
'''Teacher Training''' Currently MINDS is developing a training program, based on the [[WHO]] advocation of Task-Shifting, which trains teachers at local schools to identify and support mentally ill youth.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=World Health Organization|title=Task Shifting: Global Recommendations and Guidelines|date=2008|url=http://www.who.int/workforcealliance/knowledge/resources/taskshifting_guidelines/en/}}</ref> The program follows a four-step model focused on understanding why mental illness is a problem, identifying possible signs of mental illness in students, supporting students through active listening and de-stigmatization of classrooms and referring students to CMHWs for further consolation and screening.
'''Gender Workshops''' Additionally, MINDS is considering how discussions and education about gender-specific concerns surrounding mental illness and well-being could further deepen the Phase 1 programming.<ref name="Amanda Walker">{{cite news|title=gender education research intern|accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref>
'''Published Research''' ''Knowledge of and Attitudes Toward Clinical Depression Among Health Providers in Gujarat, India.''<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai|title=Knowledge of and Attitudes Toward Clinical Depression Among Health Providers in Gujarat, India.|pmid=24976545 | doi=10.1016/j.aogh.2014.04.001|volume=80|year=2014|journal=Ann Glob Health|pages=89–95}}</ref>
''Perceptions of Traditional Healing for Mental Illness in Rural Gujarat.''<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai|title= Perceptions of traditional healing for mental illness in rural Gujarat|pmid=24976546|doi=10.1016/j.aogh.2014.04.013|volume=80|year=2014|journal=Ann Glob Health|pages=96–102}}</ref>
== Organization and Administration<ref>{{cite web|title=Our Team|url=http://www.mindsfoundation.org/our-team/|website=The MINDS Foundation|accessdate=25 July 2014}}</ref> == In order to manage field work, project development and research, MINDS has a multi-level organizational system that combines full-time employees with professional volunteers and advisors around the world. The core team, associates and field team manage the non-profit, monitor the three-phase education treatment & reintegration program and organize ongoing research. The Global and Indian [[Board of Directors]], consisting of notable professors and professionals, monitor the progress of MINDS and support the key values of the NGO. Lastly, the Advisors offer professional advice for program development and research.
In addition to the year-round team, board and advisors, MINDS runs a Leadership Development Development Program where interns from across the US partner with members of the core team to receive training and hands-on experience in marketing, publicity, research and program development. The program aims to develop future leaders in the non-profit arena.
For students and professionals looking for [[field research|field experience]], the MINDS Fellowship Program allows volunteers to work in [[Gujarat]] on research and programing projects.
== History == The MINDS Foundation was founded as [[nonprofit]] in August 2010 and is registered in [[Massachusetts]] as an [[NGO]]; additionally it partners with an NGO of the same name located in India, and thus is run through global offices.<ref name="voices.halabol.com">{{cite journal|last1=M|first1=Anu|title=The MINDS Foundation: Fighting the Mental Illness|journal=Halabol Voices|date=2013-10-10|url=http://voices.halabol.com/2013/10/09/minds-foundation-fighting-mental-illness}}</ref> Currently MINDS runs programs in 19 villages in [[Gujarat]] and will expand to other villages in the near future.
In India, there is no official mental health policy and resources are extremely limited, with only 0.3 psychiatrists/100,000 people and just 0.06% of the national health budget going towards mental illness education and treatment.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Seervai|first1=Shanoor|title=India's Mental Health Challenge|journal=The Wall Street Journal|date=2013-10-21|url=http://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2013/10/21/indias-mental-health-challenge/}}</ref> Furthermore, rural areas in India tend to be some of the most neglected: out of 626 districts in India, only 125 have any sort of mental health program in place.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Thompson|first1=Christie|title=Reimagining Psychiatry in Rural India|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2012/09/reimagining-psychiatry-in-rural-india/262214/|website=The Atlantic}}</ref> Despite the lack of national resources and funding, "mental illness constitutes nearly one sixth of all health-related disorders".<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kumar|first1=Anat|title=Mental Health Services in Rural India: Challenges and Prospects|date=11/10/2011|url=https://www.academia.edu/1191870/Mental_health_services_in_rural_India_challenges_and_prospects}}</ref> Therefore, [[Health in India|health resources in India]] are usually funded, provided and accessed through the private sector.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ministry of Health and Family Welfare: Government of India|title=National Family Health Survey (NFHS-3): India|journal=NFHS-3|date=2005–2006|volume=1|page=436|url=http://hetv.org/india/nfhs/nfhs3/NFHS-3-IN.pdf}}</ref>
== Partners and Sponsors == The MINDS Foundation partners with [[Mount Sinai School of Medicine]] for program advice and review. MINDS also partners with [http://www.sumandeepuniversity.co.in/ Sumandeep Vidyapeeth University], located just outside [[Vadodara]]. Starting in July 2011, MINDs began working with the Departments of Psychiatry and Community Medicine at Diharaj General Hospital, which provides treatment support and local staff.<ref name="voices.halabol.com"/>
The MINDS Foundation has campus chapters at [[Wesleyan University]]<ref>{{cite web|title=The MINDS Foundation|url=https://wesep.wesleyan.edu/cgi-perl/students/wsanew/wsa_groups.cgi|website=Wesleyan University|accessdate=25 July 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120805204946/https://wesep.wesleyan.edu/cgi-perl/students/wsanew/wsa_groups.cgi|archivedate=5 August 2012|df=}}</ref> and at GlobeMed at [[University of Washington]].<ref>{{cite web|title=MINDS Foundation|url=https://globemeduw.wordpress.com/tag/minds-foundation/|website=GlobeMed at University of Washington|accessdate=25 July 2014}}</ref>
The MINDS Foundation also receives sponsorship, funding or donations from: The Mentor Network,<ref>{{cite web|title=The Mentor Network|url=http://www.thementornetwork.com|accessdate=25 July 2014}}</ref> The [[International Monetary Fund]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imf.org/external/|website=International Monetary Fund|accessdate=25 July 2014}}</ref> [[Newman's Own]] Foundation,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newmansownfoundation.org|website=Newman's Own Foundation|accessdate=25 July 2014}}</ref> [[Gray Matters Capital]],<ref>{{cite Partricelli Center for Social Entrepreneurship,<ref>{{cite web|title=Patricelli Center for Social Entrepreneurship|url=http://www.wesleyan.edu/patricelli/|website=Wesleyan University|accessdate=25 Social Innovation Challenge]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Verb U|url=http://www.dellchallenge.org/#/home|website=Dell|accessdate=25 July 2014}}</ref> StartingBloc,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://startingbloc.org|website=Starting Bloc|accessdate=25 July 2014}}</ref> mHealth Alliance<ref>{{cite web|title=mHealth Alliance|url=http://www.mhealthalliance.org|accessdate=25 July 2014}}</ref> and the Gulbenkian Mental Health Platform.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gulbenkian Mental Health Platform|url=http://www.gulbenkianmhplatform.com|accessdate=25 July 2014}}</ref>
== Further reading == NPR: ''In India, Stigma of Mental Illness Hinders Treatment''<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kennedy|first1=Miranda|title=In India, Stigma Of Mental Illness Hinders Treatment|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=129091680|website=NPR|accessdate=25 July 2014}}</ref>
The Wall Street Journal: ''India's Mental Health Challenge''<ref>{{cite web|last1=Seervai|first1=Shanoor|title=India's Mental Health Challenge|url=http://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2013/10/21/indias-mental-health-challenge/|website=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=25 July 2014}}</ref>
Halabol Voices: ''The MINDS Foundation: Fighting the Mental Illness''<ref>{{cite web|last1=M|first1=Anu|title=The MINDS Foundation: Fighting the Mental Illness|url=http://voices.halabol.com/2013/10/09/minds-foundation-fighting-mental-illness|website=Halabol Voices|accessdate=25 July 2014}}</ref>
Gulbenkian Global Mental Health Platform: ''The MINDS Foundation''<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gulbenkian|title=The MINDS Foundation|url=http://www.gulbenkianmhplatform.com/information/news?id_news=90#|website=Gulbenkian Global Mental Health Platform|accessdate=25 July 2014}}</ref>
India West: ''Youthful Approach to Battle Mental Illness Stigmas: Raghu Kiran Appasani''<ref>{{cite web|last1=LaVigne |first1=Diana |title=Youthful Approach to Battle Mental Illness Stigmas: Raghu Kiran Appasani |url=http://www.indiawest.com/news/244-blog-youthful-approach-to-battle-mental-illness-stigmas-raghu-kiran-appasani.html |website=India West |accessdate=25 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028180510/http://www.indiawest.com/news/244-blog-youthful-approach-to-battle-mental-illness-stigmas-raghu-kiran-appasani.html |archivedate=October 28, 2013 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.comment: Alter: doi-broken-date. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]]; [[Category:Pages_with_DOIs_inactive_since_2017]].
revision.text:
{{globalize|date=May 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2011}} '''Unnecessary health care''' ('''overutilization''', '''overuse''', or '''overtreatment''') is [[healthcare]] provided with a higher volume or cost than is appropriate.<ref name="Perfect Storm">{{Cite journal|author=[[Ezekiel J. Emanuel]], [[Victor R. Fuchs]]|title=The perfect storm of overutilization|journal=The Journal of the American Medical Association|volume=299|issue=23|pages=2789–91|year=2008|doi=10.1001/jama.299.23.2789|pmid=18560006|url=http://www.ipalc.org/Healthcare_Policy/The%20Perfect%20Storm%20of%20Overutilization%20%28JAMA%202008%29.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090902053119/http://www.ipalc.org/Healthcare_Policy/The%20Perfect%20Storm%20of%20Overutilization%20%28JAMA%202008%29.pdf|archivedate=September 2, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In the [[United States]], where [[health care finance in the United States|health care costs are the highest]] as a percentage of [[GDP]], overuse was the predominant factor in its expense, accounting for about a third of its healthcare spending ($750 billion out of $2.6 trillion) in 2012.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kliff|first1=Sarah|title=We spend $750 billion on unnecessary health care. Two charts explain why.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2012/09/07/we-spend-750-billion-on-unnecessary-health-care-two-charts-explain-why/|accessdate=31 March 2016|publisher=The Washington Post|date=September 7, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151230122254/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2012/09/07/we-spend-750-billion-on-unnecessary-health-care-two-charts-explain-why/|archivedate=December 30, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Factors that drive overuse include paying [[healthcare provider]]s more to do more ([[fee-for-service]]), [[defensive medicine]] to protect against [[wikt:litigiousness#Noun|litigiousness]], and insulation from [[price sensitivity]] in instances where the [[consumer]] is not the [[wikt:payer#Noun|payer]]—the [[patient]] receives goods and services but insurance pays for them (whether public insurance, private, or both).<ref>{{cite journal|author=[[Ezekiel J. Emanuel]] & [[Victor R. Fuchs]]|title=Health Care Overutilization in the United States—Reply|journal=The Journal of the American Medical Association| volume=300|issue=19|page=2251|doi=10.1001/jama.2008.605|year=2008}}</ref> Such factors leave many actors in the system (doctors, patients, pharmaceutical companies, device manufacturers) with inadequate [[incentive]] to restrain [[health care prices]] or overuse.<ref name="Perfect Storm"/><ref name="Waste"/> This drives payers, such as [[national health insurance]] systems or the U.S. [[Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services]], to focus on [[medical necessity]] as a condition for payment. However, the threshold between necessity and lack thereof can often be [[subjectivity|subjective]].
''Overtreatment'', in the strict sense, may refer to unnecessary medical interventions, including treatment of a self-limited condition (''[[overdiagnosis]]'') or to extensive treatment for a condition that requires only limited treatment.
==Definition==
A forerunner of the term was what [[Jack Wennberg]] called ''[[unwarranted variation]]'',<ref name="MoreIsLess">{{cite news |title=More is Less |author=Alix Spiegel |newspaper=[[This American Life]] |date=November 10, 2009 |url=http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/391/more-is-less |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111105005053/http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/391/more-is-less |archivedate=November 5, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> different rates of treatments based upon where people lived, not clinical rationale. He had discovered that in studies that began in 1967 and were published in the 1970s and the 1980s: "The basic premise - that medicine was driven by science and by physicians capable of making clinical decisions based on well-established fact and theory - was simply incompatible with the data we saw. It was immediately apparent that suppliers were more important in driving demand than had been previously realized."<ref>Michael T. McCue [http://www.managedhealthcareexecutive.com/mhe/article/articleDetail.jsp?id=46508 Clamping down on variation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071218052952/http://www.managedhealthcareexecutive.com/mhe/article/articleDetail.jsp?id=46508 |date=December 18, 2007 }} - Managed Healthcare Executive, February 01, 2003</ref>
In 2008, US bioethicist [[Ezekiel J. Emanuel]] and health economist [[Victor R. Fuchs]] defined unnecessary health care as "overutilization," healthcare provided with a higher volume or cost than is appropriate.<ref name="Perfect Storm"/> Recently, economists have sought to understand unnecessary health care in terms of misconsumption rather than [[overconsumption]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hensher|first=Martin|last2=Tisdell|first2=John|last3=Zimitat|first3=Craig|date=2017-03-01|title="Too much medicine": Insights and explanations from economic theory and research|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0277953617300278|journal=Social Science & Medicine|volume=176|pages=77–84|doi=10.1016/j.socscimed.2017.01.020|pmid=28131024}}</ref>
In 2009 two US physicians wrote in an editorial, that unnecessary care was "defined as services which show no demonstrable benefit to patients" and might represent 30% of U.S. medical care.<ref name="MuchAdo">{{cite journal|vauthors=Reilly BM, Evans AT | title=Much ado about (doing) nothing| journal=[[Ann Intern Med]] | year= 2009 | volume= 150 | issue= 4 | pages= 270–1 | pmc= | pmid=19221379 | doi=10.7326/0003-4819-150-4-200902170-00008| citeseerx=10.1.1.688.1277}} {{subscription}}</ref> They referred to a 2003 study on regional variations in Medicare spending, which found, "Medicare enrollees in higher-spending regions receive more care than those in lower-spending regions, but do not have better health outcomes or satisfaction with care."<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 12585826 | doi=10.7326/0003-4819-138-4-200302180-00007 | volume=138 | issue=4 | title=The implications of regional variations in Medicare spending. Part 2: health outcomes and satisfaction with care | date=February 2003 | author=Fisher ES, Wennberg DE, [[Thérèse Stukel|Stukel TA]], Gottlieb DJ, Lucas FL, Pinder EL | journal=Ann. Intern. Med. | pages=288–98}}</ref>
In January 2012, the American College of Physicians Ethics, Professionalism, and Human Rights Committee suggested that overtreatment can also be understood in contrast to 'parsimonious care', defined as "care that utilizes the most efficient means to effectively diagnose a condition and treat a patient."<ref>{{cite journal | author = Snyder L | year = 2012 | title = American College of Physicians Ethics Manual: sixth edition | url = | journal = Ann Intern Med | volume = 156 | issue = 1 Pt 2| pages = 73–104 | doi = 10.7326/0003-4819-156-1-201201031-00001 | pmid = 22213573 }}</ref>
In April 2012, Berwick, from the Institute for Healthcare Improvement, and Andrew Hackbarth from the [[RAND Corporation]] defined overtreatment as "subjecting patients to care that, according to sound science and the patients' own preferences, cannot possibly help them — care rooted in outmoded habits, supply-driven behaviors, and ignoring science." They wrote that trying to do something (treatment or testing) for all patients who might need it inevitably entails doing that same thing for some patients who might not need it." In uncertain situations, "some non-beneficial care was the necessary byproduct of optimal clinical decision making."<ref>Berwick DM, Hackbarth AD. Eliminating waste in US health care.JAMA. 2012 Apr 11;307(14):1513-6. {{doi|10.1001/jama.2012.362}}. {{subscription}}</ref>
In October 2015, two pediatricians said that considering "overtreatment as an ethical violation" could help see the conflicting incentives of healthcare workers for treatment or nontreatment.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Ralston Shawn L., Schroeder Alan R. | year = 2015 | title = Doing More vs Doing Good: Aligning Our Ethical Principles From the Personal to the Societal | url = http://archpedi.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleID=2449668 | journal = JAMA Pediatrics | volume = 169 | issue = 12| pages = 1085–6 | doi = 10.1001/jamapediatrics.2015.2702 | pmid = 26502277 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160420230628/http://archpedi.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=2449668 | archivedate = April 20, 2016 | df = mdy-all }} {{subscription}}</ref>
==Cost== In the US, the country which spends the most on healthcare per person globally, overuse is the most important contributor to the high cost.<ref name="Perfect Storm"/> ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported "chronic overuse of medical care" exists in the United States.<ref name="MayDoLittle">{{cite news |title=Law May Do Little to Help Curb Unnecessary Care |author=Gina Colata |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 29, 2010 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/30/health/30use.html |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170716030707/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/30/health/30use.html |archivedate=July 16, 2017 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Overuse of medical care costs billions of dollars every year.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Gibson |last2=Singh |first2=Rosemary |authorlink= |title=The Treatment Trap: How the Overuse of Medical Care is Wrecking Your Health |url=http://www.treatmenttrap.org |accessdate= |year=2010 |publisher=Ivan R. Dee |location=Chicago |isbn=9781566638425 |page=30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130705144002/http://www.treatmenttrap.org/ |archivedate=July 5, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> and lowers the quality of health care. The [[United States National Academy of Sciences]] estimated in 2005 that "between $.30 and $.40 of every dollar spent on healthcare is spent on the costs of poor quality," amounting to" slightly more than a half-trillion dollars a year... wasted on overuse, underuse, misuse, duplication, system failures, unnecessary repetition, poor communication, and inefficiency.<ref>{{cite book |title=Building a Better Delivery System: A New Engineering/Health Care Partnership – Bridging the Quality Chasm |last=Lawrence |first=David |year=2005 |publisher=[[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]] |location=Washington, DC |isbn=978-0-309-65406-7 |page=99 |url=http://www.nap.edu/catalog/11378.html |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080709002402/http://www.nap.edu/catalog/11378.html |archivedate=July 9, 2008 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
When care is overused, patients are put at risk of complications unnecessarily,<ref name="Biden">{{cite news |title=Medicare Options In Biden Budget Talks Get Boost |newspaper=[[NPR]] |publisher=[[The Associated Press]] |date=June 15, 2011 |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=137200637 |accessdate=June 26, 2011}}</ref> with documented harm to patients from overuse of surgeries and other treatments.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Gibson |last2=Singh |first2=Rosemary |authorlink= |title=The Treatment Trap: How the Overuse of Medical Care is Wrecking Your Health |url=http://www.treatmenttrap.org |accessdate= |year=2010 |publisher=Ivan R. Dee |location=Chicago |isbn=9781566638425 |pages=63–83 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130705144002/http://www.treatmenttrap.org/ |archivedate=July 5, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In 2003 Fisher ''et al''.<ref name="Part1">{{Cite journal | author = [[Elliott S. Fisher]], [[David E. Wennberg]], [[Thérèse Stukel|Thérèse A. Stukel]], [[Daniel J. Gottlieb]], [[F. L. Lucas]] & [[Etoile L. Pinder]] | title = The implications of regional variations in Medicare spending. Part 1: the content, quality, and accessibility of care | journal = [[Annals of Internal Medicine]] | volume = 138 | issue = 4 | pages = 273–287 | date = February 2003 | pmid = 12585825 | url = http://www.annals.org/content/138/4/273.full | doi = 10.7326/0003-4819-138-4-200302180-00006 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110102104246/http://www.annals.org/content/138/4/273.full | archivedate = January 2, 2011 | df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="Part2">{{Cite journal | author = [[Elliott S. Fisher]], [[David E. Wennberg]], [[Therese A. Stukel]], [[Daniel J. Gottlieb]], [[F. L. Lucas]] & [[Etoile L. Pinder]] | title = The implications of regional variations in Medicare spending. Part 2: health outcomes and satisfaction with care | journal = [[Annals of Internal Medicine]] | volume = 138 | issue = 4 | pages = 288–298 | date = February 2003 | pmid = 12585826 | url = http://www.annals.org/content/138/4/288.short | doi = 10.7326/0003-4819-138-4-200302180-00007 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110630161541/http://www.annals.org/content/138/4/288.short | archivedate = June 30, 2011 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> found that "there is no apparent regional health benefit for [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]] recipients from doing more, whether 'more' is expressed as hospitalizations, surgical procedures, or consultations within the hospital."<ref name="Reflections">{{Cite journal | author=[[Steven A. Schroeder]] | title = Personal reflections on the high cost of American medical care: Many causes but few politically sustainable solutions | journal=[[Archives of Internal Medicine]] | volume = 171 | issue = 8 | pages = 722–727 |date=April 2011 | doi = 10.1001/archinternmed.2011.149 | pmid = 21518938}}</ref> Up to 30% of Medicare spending may be cut without harming patients.<ref name="Part2"/>
==Causes== Physicians' decisions are the [[proximate cause]] of unnecessary care, though the potential incentives and penalties they face can influence their choices.
===Third-party payers and fee-for-service=== {{See also|Fee-for-service}}
When public or private insurance cover expenses and doctors are paid under a [[fee-for-service]] (FFS) model, neither has an [[incentive]] to consider the cost of treatment, a combination that contributes to waste.<ref name="Waste">{{Cite journal | author=[[Victor R. Fuchs]] | title = Eliminating 'waste' in health care | journal=[[JAMA: The Journal of the American Medical Association]] | volume = 302 | issue = 22 | pages = 2481–2482 |date=December 2009 | doi = 10.1001/jama.2009.1821 | pmid = 19996406}}</ref> Fee-for-service is a large incentive for overuse because health care providers (such as doctors and hospitals) receive revenue from the overtreatment.<ref name="Perfect Storm"/>
[[Atul Gawande]] investigated Medicare FFS reimbursements in [[McAllen, Texas]], for a 2009 article in the ''New Yorker''.<ref>{{cite news |title=Texas town's healthcare puzzle |author=Katty Kay |newspaper=BBC News |date=July 7, 2009 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/8137085.stm |accessdate=June 19, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100216214634/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/8137085.stm |archivedate=February 16, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | author=[[Bryant Furlow]] | title = US reimbursement systems encourage fraud and overutilisation | journal=[[The Lancet Oncology]] | volume = 10 | issue = 10 | pages = 937–938 |date=October 2009 | pmid = 19810157 | doi = 10.1016/S1470-2045(09)70297-9}}</ref> In 2006, the town of McAllen was the second-most expensive Medicare market, behind [[Miami]]. Costs per beneficiary were almost twice the national average.<ref name="Conundrum">{{cite news |title=The Cost Conundrum – What a Texas town can teach us about health care |author=[[Atul Gawande]] |newspaper=''The New Yorker'' |date=June 1, 2009 |url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2009/06/01/090601fa_fact_gawande?currentPage=all |accessdate=June 29, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110610174307/http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2009/06/01/090601fa_fact_gawande?currentPage=all |archivedate=June 10, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In 1992, however, McAllen had been almost exactly in line with the Medicare spending average.<ref name="Conundrum"/> After looking at other potential explanations such as relatively poorer health or medical malpractice, Gawande concluded the town was a chief example of the overuse of medical services.<ref name="SpendMore">{{cite news |title=Spend More, Get Less? The Health Care 'Conundrum' |newspaper=[[Fresh Air]] |publisher=[[NPR]] |date=June 17, 2009 |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=105483669 |accessdate=June 29, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140328041112/http://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=105483669 |archivedate=March 28, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Gawande concluded that a business culture (physicians viewing their practices as a revenue stream) had established itself there, in contrast to a culture of low-cost high-quality medicine at the [[Mayo Clinic]] and in the [[Grand Junction, Colorado]], market.<ref name="Conundrum"/><ref name="SpendMore"/> Gawande advised:{{quotation|As America struggles to extend healthcare coverage while curbing [[health care prices in the United States|health care costs]], we face a decision that is more important than whether we have a public-insurance option, more important than whether we will have a single-payer system in the long run or a mixture of public and private insurance, as we do now. The decision is whether we are going to reward the leaders who are trying to build a new generation of Mayos and Grand Junctions. If we don't, McAllen won't be an outlier. It will be our future.<ref name="Conundrum"/>}}
===Medical malpractice laws and defensive medicine=== {{See also|Medical malpractice}} To protect themselves from legal prosecution U.S. physicians have an incentive to order clinically unnecessary tests or tests of little potential value.<ref name="Perfect Storm"/> While [[defensive medicine]] is a favored explanation for high medical costs by physicians, Gawande estimated in 2010 it only contributed to 2.4% of the total $2.3 trillion of U.S. health care spending in 2008.<ref name="Reflections"/><ref>{{Cite journal | author=Michelle M. Mello, Amitabh Chandra, Atul A. Gawande & David M. Studdert | title = National costs of the medical liability system| journal=[[Health Affairs (Project Hope)]] | volume = 29 | issue = 9 | pages = 1569–1577 |date=September 2010 | doi = 10.1377/hlthaff.2009.0807 | pmid = 20820010 | pmc=3048809}}</ref>
===Direct-to-consumer advertising===
[[Direct-to-consumer advertising]] can encourage patients to ask for drugs, devices, diagnostics, or procedures. Sometimes service providers will simply give these treatments or services rather than attempting the potentially more unpleasant task of convincing the patient what they have requested is not needed, or is likely to cause more harm than good.<ref name="Perfect Storm"/>
===Physician predispositions ===
Dartmouth Medical School professor Gilbert Welch argued 2016 that certain predispositions by physicians and the general public may lead to unnecessary health care, including:<ref>Gilbert Welch [https://www.acponline.org/sites/default/files/documents/about_acp/chapters/ut/16mtg/welch.pdf Assumptions That Drive Too Much Medical Care] American College of Physicians, n.d., retrieved 9 May 2018 </ref><ref>{{cite book| title=Less Medicine, More Health |author=Gilbert Welch |year=2016 |publisher=Beacon Press |isbn=978-0807077580 }}</ref> * Attempting to mitigate a risk without considering how small or unlikely the potential benefit is * Attempting to fix an underlying problem, instead of using a less-risky monitoring or coping strategy * Acting too quickly, when waiting for more information might be wiser * Acting without considering the benefits of doing nothing * Discounting downsides of diagnostic testing * Preferring newer over older treatments without considering the cost of new treatments or the effectiveness of older ones * Treating patients with terminal illness to maximize life span over quality of life, without probing a patient´s preferences
==Examples==
===Imaging=== Overuse of diagnostic imaging, such as X-rays and CT scans, is defined as any application unlikely to improve patient care.<ref name="Globally">{{Cite journal | author=[[B. Rehani]] | title = Imaging overutilisation: Is enough being done globally? | journal=[[Biomedical Imaging and Intervention Journal]] | volume = 7 | issue = 1 | pages = e6 |date=January 2011 | doi = 10.2349/biij.7.1.e6 | pmid = 21655115 | pmc = 3107688| doi-broken-date = 2018-09-21 }}</ref> Factors that contribute to overuse include "[[Physician self-referral|self-referral]], patient wishes, inappropriate financially motivated factors, health system factors, industry, media, lack of awareness" and [[defensive medicine]].<ref name="Globally"/> Respected organizations—such as the [[American College of Radiology]] (ACR), [[Royal College of Radiologists]] (RCR) and the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO)—have developed "appropriateness criteria".<ref name="Globally"/> The Canadian Association of Radiologists estimated in 2009 that 30% of imaging was unnecessary in the [[Health care in Canada|Canadian health care system]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.car.ca/uploads/patient%20info/car_cat_scan_eng.pdf |title=Do you need that scan? |year=2009 |publisher=[[Canadian Association of Radiologists]] |accessdate=June 27, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110322052940/http://www.car.ca/uploads/patient%20info/car_cat_scan_eng.pdf |archivedate=March 22, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> 2008 Medicare claims showed overuse with chest CT's.<ref>{{cite news |title=Medicare Claims Show Overuse for CT Scanning |author1=Walt Bogdanich |author2=Jo Craven McGinty |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 17, 2011 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/18/health/18radiation.html |accessdate=June 22, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zcfYCb5l?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/18/health/18radiation.html?_r=2 |archivedate=June 22, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Financial incentives have also been shown to have a significant impact on dental X-ray use with dentists who are paid a separate fee for each X-ray providing more X-rays. <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Chalkley|first1=M.|last2=Listl|first2=S.|title=First do no harm – The impact of financial incentives on dental X-rays|journal=Journal of Health Economics|date=30 December 2017|doi=10.1016/j.jhealeco.2017.12.005|pmid=29408150|volume=58|issue=March 2018|pages=1–9}}</ref>
Overuse of imaging can lead to a diagnosis of a condition that would have otherwise remained irrelevant ([[overdiagnosis]]).<ref>{{Cite journal | author=[[Elm Ho]] | title = Overuse, overdose, overdiagnosis... overreaction? | journal=[[Biomedical Imaging and Intervention Journal]] | volume = 6 | issue = 3 | pages = e8 |date=July 2010 | doi = 10.2349/biij.6.3.e8 | pmid = 21611049 | pmc = 3097773}}</ref>
====Physician self-referral==== {{Main|Physician self-referral}} One type of overuse can be physician self-referral.<ref name="Turf">{{Cite journal | author=[[David C. Levin]] & [[Vijay M. Rao]] | title = Turf wars in radiology: the overutilization of imaging resulting from self-referral | journal=[[Journal of the American College of Radiology : JACR]] | volume = 1 | issue = 3 | pages = 169–172 |date=March 2004 | doi = 10.1016/j.jacr.2003.12.009 | pmid = 17411553 }}</ref> Multiple studies have replicated the finding that when non-radiologists have an ownership interest in the fees generated by radiology equipment—and can self-refer—their use of imaging is unnecessarily higher.<ref name="Turf"/> The majority of U.S. growth in imaging use (the fastest-growing physician service) comes from self-referring nonradiologists.<ref name="Turf"/> In 2004, this overuse was estimated to contribute to $16 billion of annual U.S. health care costs.<ref name="Turf"/>
As of a 2018 review evidence of overtreatment overmedicalization, and overdiagnosis in Pediatrics have been use of commercial rehydration solution, antidepressants, and parenteral nutrition; overmedicalization with planned early deliveries, immobilization of ankle injuries, use of hydrolyzed infant formula; and overdiagnosis of hypoxemia among children recovering from bronchiolitis. <ref>2017 Update on Pediatric Medical Overuse. A Review. JAMA Pediatr. 2018;172(5):482-486. doi:10.1001/jamapediatrics.2017.5752</ref> ===Others===
*Hospitalizations<ref>{{Cite journal | title = Do doctors under-provide, over-provide or do both? Accessed August 22, 2011.</ref>
==Reduction efforts== [[Utilization management]] (utilization review) has evolved over decades among both public and private payers in an attempt to reduce overuse. In this effort, insurers employ physicians to review the actions of other physicians and detect overuse. Utilization review has a poor reputation among most clinicians as a corrupted system in which utilization reviewers have their own [[perverse incentive]]s (i.e., find ways to deny coverage no matter what) and in some cases are not practicing physicians, lacking real-world clinical insight or wisdom.
The 2010 U.S. health care reform, the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]], did not contain serious strategies to reduce overuse; "the public has made it clear that it does not want to be told what medical care it can and cannot have."<ref name="MayDoLittle"/> [[Uwe Reinhardt]], a health economist at Princeton, said "the minute you attack overutilization, you will be called a Nazi before the day is out".<ref name="MayDoLittle"/>
Professional societies and other groups have begun to push for policy changes that would encourage clinicians to avoid providing unnecessary care. Most physicians accept that laboratory tests are overused, but "it remains difficult to persuade them to consider the possibility that they, too, might be overutilizing laboratory tests."<ref>{{Cite journal | author=[[Jamie A. Weydert]], [[Newell D. Nobbs]], [[Ronald Feld]] & [[John D. Kemp]] | title = A simple, focused, computerized query to detect overutilization of laboratory tests | journal=[[Archives of Pathology & Laboratory Medicine]] | volume = 129 | issue = 9 | pages = 1141–1143 |date=September 2005 | doi = 10.1043/1543-2165(2005)129[1141:ASFCQT]2.0.CO;2 | pmid = 16119987 | doi-broken-date = 2018-09-21 }}</ref> In November 2011, the [[ABIM Foundation|American Board of Internal Medicine Foundation]] began the [[Choosing Wisely]] campaign, which aims to raise awareness of overtreatment and change physician behavior by publicizing lists of tests and treatments that are often overused, and which doctors and patients should try to avoid.{{citation needed|date=March 2017}}
In April 2012, the Lown Institute and the [[New America Foundation]] Health Policy Program convened the 'Avoiding Avoidable Care'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://avoidablecare.org/|title=Avoiding Avoidable Care|website=avoidablecare.org|accessdate=January 19, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150103154604/http://avoidablecare.org/ |archivedate=January 3, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> conference. It was the first major medical conference to focus entirely on overuse, and it included presentations from speakers including [[Bernard Lown]], [[Don Berwick]], [[Christine Cassel]], Amitabh Chandra,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hks.harvard.edu/about/faculty-staff-directory/amitabh-chandra|title=Harvard Kennedy School - Amitabh Chandra|author=Harvard Kennedy School|website=harvard.edu|accessdate=January 19, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150111121107/http://www.hks.harvard.edu/about/faculty-staff-directory/amitabh-chandra|archivedate=January 11, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> [[JudyAnn Bigby]], and [[Julio Frenk]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Featured Speakers {{!}} Avoiding Avoidable Care|url=http://avoidablecare.org/about-the-conference/speakers/|accessdate=21 August 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130814013018/http://avoidablecare.org/about-the-conference/speakers/ |archivedate=August 14, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> A second meeting was planned for December 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=2013 Lown Conference: From Avoidable Care to Right Care|url=http://www.lowninstitute.org/project/2013-lown-conference/|publisher=Lown Institute|accessdate=21 August 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104115823/http://lowninstitute.org/project/2013-lown-conference/|archivedate=November 4, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Since the meeting, the Lown Institute has focused its work on deepening the understanding of overuse and generating public discussion of the ethical and cultural drivers of overuse, especially on the role of the [[hidden curriculum]] in medical school and [[Residency (medicine)|residency]].{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}
Patient safety committees, which are charged with reviewing the quality of care, can view overutilization as [[adverse event]].<ref>{{cite journal | author = Zapata Josué A., Lai Andrew R., Moriates Christopher | year = 2017 | title = Is Excessive Resource Utilization an Adverse Event? | url = | journal = JAMA | volume = 317 | issue = 8| pages = 849–850 | doi = 10.1001/jama.2017.0698 | pmid = 28245327 | doi-broken-date = 2018-09-21 }}</ref>

10 years probation | conviction_status = [[Probation]] | spouse = | children = | parents = | motive = | conviction = [[assisted suicide|Assisting suicide]], attempted assisting suicide | victims = 5 (self-claimed)
2 (convicted) | date = | time = | beginyear = | endyear = | country = | states = | locations = | targets = | fatalities = | injuries = | weapons = | apprehended = 2011 | imprisoned = | module = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} '''William Francis Melchert-Dinkel''' (born July 20, 1962) is an [[United States|American]] former [[licensed practical nurse]] (LPN). In 2011, he was found guilty of encouraging people to commit [[suicide]].[http://www.cbc.ca/news/pdf/melchert-dinkel-complaint.pdf Complaint]{{cite news|last=Davey |first=Monica |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/14/us/14suicide.html |title=Online Talk, Suicides and a Thorny Court Case |publisher=The New York Times |date=May 13, 2010 |accessdate=June 26, 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/nurse-may-be-linked-to-multiple-suicides-tracker-says/article1154777/|title=Nurse may be linked to multiple suicides, tracker says|last=Anderssen|first=Erin|date=April 10, 2009|publisher=[[The Globe and Mail]]|location=Toronto|accessdate=April 14, 2016}}{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/article/631689 |title=Nurse urged 5 to commit suicide, U.S. police say |work=Toronto Star |date=May 9, 2009 |accessdate=June 26, 2010 |first=Robyn |last=Doolittle}}[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article7107061.ece "William Melchert-Dinkel charged with encouraging suicides], ''[[The Sunday Times]]'', April 24, 2010. Retrieved June 26, 2010. He allegedly told those contemplating suicide what methods worked best, that it was a decent choice to commit suicide, that they would be better off in heaven, and/or falsely entered into [[suicide pact]]s with them.{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/ontario/article/594553 |title=Teen urged to commit suicide on webcam |publisher=[[The Toronto Star]]|date=February 28, 2009 |accessdate=June 26, 2010 |first=Robyn |last=Doolittle}} He is a married father of two.{{cite news|author=Niall Firth |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1259379/The-suicide-voyeur-nurse-encouraged-people-kill-online.html |title=The suicide voyeur nurse who 'encouraged people to kill themselves online'|publisher=[[Daily Mail]] |date=March 24, 2010 |accessdate=June 26, 2010 |location=London}}{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/33349974/ |title=Cops: Nurse encouraged suicides |publisher=MSNBC |date=October 16, 2009 |accessdate=June 27, 2010}}[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/18/us/18suicides.html "Nurse Is Accused of Using Internet to Encourage Suicides"], The New York Times, October 18, 2009 Melchert-Dinkel was originally convicted of two counts of [[assisted suicide|assisting suicide]] for encouraging the July 27, 2005 suicide of 36-year-old Mark Drybrough,[https://billiongraves.com/grave/MARK-SCOTT-DRYBROUGH/9373685 Mark Drybrough page at BillionGraves] a [[British people|British]] [[Information technology|IT]] technician, and the April 20, 2008 suicide of 20-year-old Nadia Kajouji, a student at [[Carleton University]] in [[Ottawa]], [[Canada]][https://nationalpost.com/rss/more+light+shed+suspect+kajouji+death/1336185/story.html More light shed on suspect in Kajouji death] via [[Internet]] [[chat room]]s. Those convictions were later overturned by the [[Minnesota]] [[Minnesota Supreme Court|Supreme Court]] when it found that part of the state law used to convict him was unconstitutional. On [[Remand (detention)|remand]], Melchert-Dinkel was convicted on one count of assisting suicide, and one count of attempted assisting suicide. He served 178 days in jail and will be on [[probation]] for ten years.[http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/william-melchert-dinkel-ex-nurse-who-encouraged-suicides-out-of-jail-1.2962770 William Melchert-Dinkel, ex-nurse who encouraged suicides, out of jail] ==Victims== William Francis Melchert-Dinkel allegedly met his victims in internet suicide [[chat room]]s, where he posed as a depressed woman in her 20s using aliases such as "Cami D" or "falcongirl". According to his affidavit, Melchert-Dinkel spoke to dozens of people over the course of four or five years, encouraging them to kill themselves (typically by hanging). He said he was successful in at least five instances.{{cite news|author= |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/technology/man-tells-police-he-coached-5-people-to-kill-themselves/article4316086/ |title=Man tells police he coached 5 people to kill themselves |publisher=The Globe and Mail |date=May 9, 2009 |accessdate=May 4, 2016 |location=Toronto |first=Josh |last=Wingrove}} ===Nadia Kajouji; Canada=== [[image:rideauriver.jpg|thumb|left|The [[Rideau River]], opposite [[Carleton University]].]] Melchert-Dinkel was convicted in relation to the suicide of 18-year-old Nadia Kajouji, who became depressed after leaving home to begin university.{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Nightline/minnesota-man-assisted-internet-suicide/story?id=10855796 |title=Minnesota Man Assisted Internet Suicide |publisher=ABC News |date= |accessdate=June 27, 2010}} A resident at Ottawa's [[Carleton University]], she jumped from a bridge and was found drowned in the [[Rideau River]] downstream from the [[Ottawa]] school in April 2008.{{cite news|url=http://ottawa.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20090227/OTT_Kajouji_Follo_090227/20090227/?hub=Ottawa}}{{cite news|author= |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/technology/depressed-maybe-youd-better-stay-off-the-web/article1149351/ |title=Depressed? 28, 2009 |accessdate=June 26, 2010 |first=Robyn |last=Doolittle}}{{cite news|url=http://cnews.canoe.ca/CNEWS/Crime/2009/02/28/8566841-sun.html |title=More online suicide chat cases sought |publisher=The Ottawa Sun |date= |accessdate=June 26, 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://nationalpost.com/news/story.html?id=2943537 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20100425035721/http://www.nationalpost.com/news/story.html?id=2943537 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=April 25, 2010 |title=U.S. man charged with inciting Ottawa student's suicide |publisher=National Post |date= |accessdate=June 27, 2010 }} Ottawa police decided not to charge Melchert-Dinkel under the Canadian assisted suicide law.{{cite news|last=Greenberg |first=Lee |url=https://ottawacitizen.com/news/Police+wrap+case+against+online+suicide+predator/2613562/story.html |title=Kajouji case goes to U.S. prosecutor |publisher=[[Ottawa Citizen]] |date=February 25, 2010 |accessdate=June 26, 2010}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ===Mark Drybrough; England=== He was also convicted in relation to the suicide of Mark Drybrough, a 32-year-old IT technician who in the wake of suffering a [[nervous breakdown]] and being depressed hanged himself in his [[Coventry]], England home in July 2005, after allegedly chatting for two months with someone allegedly using the aliases Falcongirl and Li Do.{{cite news|author=Jody Ambrozjody |url=http://www.myfoxtwincities.com/dpp/news/minnesota/william-melchert-dinkel-suicide-pacts-online-apr-23-2010 |title=Minnesota Nurse Charged in Suicides of Nadia Kajouji, Mark Drybrough |publisher=Fox News |date=January 21, 2009 |accessdate=June 27, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://news.oneindia.in/2010/04/24/us-man-helps-people-kill-themselves-over-internet.html |title=Man Aids Suicide Over Internet | Chat Rooms | Two Kill Themselves|publisher=Oneindia News|date=April 24, 2010 |accessdate=June 27, 2010}} Melchert-Dinkel was charged with counseling Drybrough on how to kill himself. ==Investigations== In November 2006, Celia Blay, a retired British schoolteacher living in [[Maiden Bradley]], [[Wiltshire]], received word from a teenaged friend in [[South America]] that she had entered a suicide pact with a young nurse. Blay investigated Melchert-Dinkel's "Li Do" identity and discovered that he had previously agreed to earlier suicide pacts. She convinced the girl to break the pact four hours before the planned suicide, saving her life. Throughout the following year, Blay posted warnings about "Li Do" on other chat websites. She also discovered Melchert-Dinkel's "Falcongirl" and "Cami D" identities, and talked to users who entered other pacts in which he arranged to have attempted victims die in front of their webcams. After months of collecting evidence about the then-unidentified Melchert-Dinkel's activities, Blay approached the local police. They opted not to investigate. In January 2008—around the time Melchert-Dinkel was corresponding with Kajouji—Blay and a friend, Kat Lowe, set up a [[sting operation|sting]] to catch "Cami D" in the act of attempting a suicide pact. It was during this correspondence that Melchert-Dinkel described seeing a man from [[Birmingham]], thought to be Drybrough, hang himself on his webcam. Lowe and Blay gained Melchert-Dinkel's trust and found information that traced him back to his [[IP address]] and residence in [[Saint Paul, Minnesota]]. In a stroke of luck, they also saw Melchert-Dinkel through a webcam feed, posing as "Cami D". Blay submitted an [[affidavit]] on the matter to the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]], but received no response. However, the [[Saint Paul Police Department]] and the Minnesota Internet Crimes Against Children Task Force agreed to take the case.[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article7069144.ece?token=null&offset=0&page=1 Village sleuth unmasks US internet predator behind suicide ‘pacts’], ''The Times'' of London, 20 March 2010''[[The Fifth Estate (TV)|The Fifth Estate]]'' -- "[http://www.cbc.ca/fifth/2009-2010/death_online/]", Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, 9 October 2009 ==Charges== [[File:RiceCountyCourthouse.JPG|right|thumb|Rice County Courthouse]] Melchert-Dinkel was convicted on March 15, 2011, in a criminal complaint filed in [[Rice County, Minnesota]]. He was charged with advising, encouraging, or assisting Kajouji and Drybrough in taking their own lives using internet correspondence.{{cite news|last=Williams |first=Chris |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/36739748/ns/us_news-crime_and_courts/ |title=Nurse charged with aiding suicides via Internet |publisher=MSNBC |date=April 23, 2010 |accessdate=June 27, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/world/archives/2010/04/25/2003471413 |title=US man charged with aiding suicides via the Web|publisher=[[Taipei Times]] |date=April 25, 2010 |accessdate=June 27, 2010}} He was ordered to not use the Internet while the case was underway.{{cite news|last= |first= |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/26/us/26brfs-NOINTERNETFO_BRF.html |title=No Internet for Man Charged in Suicides |publisher= The New York Times |date=May 25, 2010 |accessdate=June 27, 2010}} While counseling to commit suicide is illegal, laws in North America and Britain had not previously been successfully used to prosecute anyone for [[promoting suicide]] over the internet. He was found guilty of aiding a suicide under Minnesota law, which provides penalties for anyone who "intentionally advises, encourages, or assists another in taking the other's own life", punishment can be up to 15 years in prison and a fine of up to $30,000.{{cite news|url=http://cnews.canoe.ca/CNEWS/Crime/2009/02/28/8566841-sun.html |title=More online suicide chat cases sought |publisher=Cnews |date= |accessdate=June 26, 2010}} He was sentenced on May 4, 2011, to 360 days in jail.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/story/2011/05/04/aiding-suicides-sentence.html |title=Man who aided Ont. teen's suicide gets year in jail |publisher=CBC |accessdate=May 4, 2011 |date=May 4, 2011}} On July 27, 2012, the Minnesota Court of Appeals affirmed the conviction. The Minnesota Supreme Court subsequently agreed to review the case. On March 19, 2014, the supreme court reversed the conviction and remanded.http://richardclem.com/casesummaries/MelchertDinkel.html The high court held that the Minnesota statute under which Melchert-Dinkel had been convicted was unconstitutional in part. The court held that merely advising or encouraging suicide was speech protected by the First Amendment of the U.S. Constitution, and that those prohibitions were unconstitutional. It went on to hold, however, that speech which actually assisted a suicide was not protected. Since the trial court made factual findings only with respect to encouraging and advising, the supreme court reversed the conviction. It remanded, the case, however, for the lower court to determine whether Melchert-Dinkel had actually assisted the suicides within the meaning of the statute. ===Retrial and second conviction=== On October 15, 2014, Rice County District Judge Thomas Neuville sentenced William Melchert-Dinkel to 3 years in prison, but suspended that sentence if Melchert-Dinkel serves 360 days in jail and abides by the terms of his probation for 10 years after his release. A month prior to the sentencing, Judge Neuville found that Melchert-Dinkel "intentionally advised and encouraged" Drybrough and Kajouji to commit suicide, after the case had been remanded by the Minnesota Supreme Court.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2014/10/15/william-melchert-dinkel_n_5989372.html |title=William Melchert-Dinkel Sentencing: Former Nurse Tried To Assist Canadian's Suicide |publisher=Huffington Post |date= Dec 15, 2014 |accessdate=June 17, 2015}} Melchert-Dinkel was convicted of assisting the suicide of Mark Drybough and attempting to assist the suicide of Nadia Kajouji, because she ultimately took her own life by jumping off a bridge into a frozen river, rather than by hanging, as Melchert-Dinkel had allegedly suggested to her online. During his second sentencing hearing, Melchert-Dinkel stated, "I am sorry... for my actions and what I have done. I have repented."{{cite news|url=http://www.mprnews.org/story/2014/09/09/assisted-suicide-ex-nurse |title=Judge convicts ex-nurse of assisting suicide |publisher=The Associated Press |date= Sep 9, 2014 |accessdate=June 17, 2015}} William Melchert-Dinkel reported to jail on October 24, 2014. Even after his release from prison in February 2015, his lawyer has continued to appeal the conviction.{{cite news |last= Phenow |first= Brad |date= October 8, 2015 |title= Melchert-Dinkel's attorney to continue arguing until his client sees acquittal |url= http://www.southernminn.com/faribault_daily_news/article_b653aa20-4337-5b1a-8107-29b101d48cce.html |newspaper= Faribault Daily News |location= Faribault, Minnesota |access-date= December 10, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160727201857/http://www.southernminn.com/faribault_daily_news/article_b653aa20-4337-5b1a-8107-29b101d48cce.html|archivedate=July 27, 2016}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.cbc.ca/news/pdf/melchert-dinkel-complaint.pdf ''Minnesota v. Melcher-Dinkel''], Complaint, April 23, 2010 * [http://www.cyberpresse.ca/le-droit/actualites/ottawa-est-ontarien/200903/01/01-832321-un-infirmier-americain-dans-leau-chaude.php "Un infirmier américain dans l'eau chaude"], ''[[Le Droit]]'' (French), March 1, 2009 * [http://www.informador.com.mx/internacional/2009/146439/6/enfermero-alentaba-a-suicidas-potenciales-por-internet.htm "Enfermero alentaba a suicidas potenciales por Internet"], Inforamador (Spanish), October 17, 2009 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100328072714/http://tvnoviny.sk/spravy/svet/american-nabadal-cez-chat-tinedzerov-na-samovrazdu.html Američan nabádal cez chat tínedžerov na samovraždu "Američan nabádal cez chat tínedžerov na samovraždu"], ''TVnoviny'' (Slovak), March 20, 2010 * [http://haber.mynet.com/detay/dunya/bu-da-intihar-rontgencisi/501442 "Bu da intihar röntgencisi!"], Mynet.haber (Turkish), March 21, 2010 * [http://www.ad.nl/ad/nl/1013/Buitenland/article/detail/471583/2010/03/22/Man-moedigt-mensen-aan-zelfmoord-te-plegen-voor-webcam.dhtml "Man moedigt mensen aan zelfmoord te plegen voor webcam"], ''AD Buitenland'' (Dutch), March 22, 2010 * [http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/dunya/14176043.asp?scr=1 "İnternette intihar ettiriyor"], ''[[Hurriyet]]'' (Turkish), March 22, 2010 * [http://www.milliyet.com.tr/intihar-rontgencisi-4-kisiyi-oldurmus-/yasam/haberdetayarsiv/22.03.2010/1214544/default.htm "İntihar röntgencisi 4 kişiyi öldürmüş!"], Millyet.com (Turkish), March 22, 2010 * [http://www.radio-canada.ca/regions/ottawa/2010/04/23/001-suicide-etudiante-accusation.shtml "Suicide d'une étudiante d'Ottawa; Un internaute américain est accusé"], ''Radio-Canada'' (French), April 23, 2010 * [http://www.estado.com.br/noticias/internacional,ex-enfermeiro-americano-e-acusado-de-encorajar-suicidios-via-web,542261,0.htm-enfermeiro americano é acusado de encorajar suicídios via web "Ex-enfermeiro americano é acusado de encorajar suicídios via web"], ''Estadão'' (Portuguese), April 23, 2010 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100613130028/http://www30.24h.com.vn/an-ninh-hinh-su/bi-an-vu-tu-sat-qua-mang-ky-cuoi-c51a300081.html "Bí ẩn vụ tự sát qua mạng (kỳ cuối)"], 24h (Vietnamese), June 11, 2010 {{DEFAULTSORT:Melchert-Dinkel, William Francis}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Suicide in the United States]] [[Category:People from Faribault, Minnesota]] [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:American nurses]] [[Category:American women nurses]] [[Category:Suicide and the Internet]] [[Category:Criminals from Minnesota]] [[Category:American male criminals]] [[Category:21st-century American criminals]]
